question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: In the course, I developed critical thinking skills when examining labels and concepts like Latino and Latinidad. I learned about the history of the Latinx community in the United States and gained insight into issues like discrimination and assimilation that followed mass migration. I learned about the relevance of music in Latinx culture and thought about the many ways it can be used to express and explore culture.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
Coming into the class, I had some pretty big assumptions about the general content of the class. At first, I didn't think the course was going to center on US Latinx studies; I thought it was
going to focus on the history of Latin American countries and how those become affected by US intervention. Personally, I truly enjoy the direction the course is going. Learning about the history
of Latinos in the US, their struggles, their legacy, is a rich topic that I had previously not had the resources to understand. I've always wanted to learn more about this but I've never really had
the impetus to do so. I think it is so interesting to talk about these historical events, like the Chicano movement or the labor strikes, and tell my friends about them. It's a part of history that
goes unnoticed and it's worthy of bringing up everyone once in a while during a conversation. Outside of that, I feel like this class has made me more conscious of the continual Latino
presence in the US and what people are doing to combat injustice. I've done research and learned about powerful organizations, both in North Carolina and my hometown of Miami. It's
amazing seeing that everywhere there are communities like these all fighting for visibility and justice. I gain a lot from the music component of the course, and connect it to other music classes I've
taken at Duke. It's interesting seeing the connection between how the music we study is composed and what the music is representing. Understanding the Chicano movement through
song is a beautiful way to look at history. A song I particularly found touching was "Urbano's song". It was by far one of the saddest songs I've heard this year, and I still listen to it in my
 spare time.More concisely I learned:
- How to analyze Latino history and research topics in Latino studies.
- How to make a community facing project 
- How service learning can be used to supplement a class as well as engage with the surrounding community.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The instructor did an amazing job. I was always engaged in the material, mostly because she presented it well. Her fun personality made every class enjoyable, and her kindness made asking questions very easy. Since she was a great teacher, students were able to feel comfortable in class, and a great classroom culture/community was born. I would keep all methods of instruction, especially the slides used every class (the warm-ups helped me review concepts, and I loved how new information was presented).

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: After 5 semesters at Duke, Profe Carson is easily one of the best teacher's I've had. Her genuine enthusiasm, passion for the subject, love for her students, and excitement to see us grow was my primary motivation for this semester. I genuinely wish she could keep teaching me Spanish throughout my time at Duke. You can clearly tell that she loves what she does and she's also excellent at teaching- she's clear, warm, and great at providing feedback in a constructive way.Critically, she taught us new grammar in English, and this is EASILY the most helpful thing she's done. It's impossible to learn a new topic while simultaneously trying to translate in your head, so it was super helpful.The structure of the class- warm-up, low-stakes activities, and lots of opportunity to practice- made the language feel less like a memorization exercise and something I looked forward to every morning.The ability to collaborate with my peers, the different kinds of activities we did-but most importantly, Profe Carson herself- made me a more efficient learner than I've been in years.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I absolutely loved Profe Carson's teaching style. She made the classroom environment so much fun and very relaxed. I love that there was always no pressure and it made if so much easier to learn without being afraid of messing up. The structure of the course is very simple and clean and i think that makes it much easier to learn and retain information. I am a big fan of the review activities we do at the beginning of every class. I like that the class wasn't like a lecture. When we had things we needed to learn, for example grammar bursts, Profe Carson didn't sit there and lecture us for more than 5-10 min. It was always so conversational and hands-on learning which really benefited me and accommodated to my language learning style.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Overall, Professor Fernandez fostered a welcoming, forgiving learning environment in which I felt comfortable participating and putting myself out there, even if that meant making mistakes. I really enjoyed having Professor Fernandez as the course instructor. She is one of the kindest, most understanding, and encouraging professors I've ever had. This said, I did not like the Blink Platform, interactive textbooks, or quizzes (which I understand Professor Fernandez has no control over). The interactive platform felt more like tedious work than a tool to check our understanding. Similarly, the quizzes were always overly specific, and I don't think they provide accurate measures of our engagement or understanding of the course material. This aside, I absolutely LOVE Professor Fernandez, and I think she is the perfect instructor for this course. I gained confidence, and she pushed me in all of the right ways.

I think the main skills developed were an ability to use Spanish vocabulary and grammar to really speak with other students, and the ability to write in Spanish to respond to various prompts and express things about ourself in another language.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The instructor facilitated learning by actively engaging the class throughout our classtime. Rather than just lecturing, we'd review some material and then immediately work on it with partners and try to work out our weaknesses. I think the immediate. group review made class much more engaging because we learned from each other rather than just the professor, and challenged ourselves to do well before just receiving answers. In addition we did group projects and outside assignments that were genuinely interesting: thinking about how fashion or technology has changed since decades in the past and doing speaking assignments similar to what we might do for a job interview. Overall, the class's components and structures greatly facilitated learning and I'd keep all of them.

response_text: Mar is nice but this was a bit more difficult than it should have been for an intro course. Not impossible to get a good grade because she's a lenient grader if you show effort, but you're responsible for teaching yourself a lot of content based on the textbook in order to complete the daily homework. Concepts are quickly gone over after the fact, so you really need to find outside resources. In class, she speaks quickly in and basically only in Spanish. Sometimes it can be awkward because you have no idea what she's saying. You'll be participating a lot and it's a big part of your grade. Lots of group projects.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: The small seminar class has helped facilitate various conversations that reflected some of the feelings of the students in the class. Majority of us have some sort of tie to Latin America and being able to talk about and relate to common experiences we have faced has been very validating. question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned lots about different kinds of Latin American music, political movements, and the story behind words like Latinidad or ones that are equally or even more controversial like Malinche.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: In the course, I developed critical thinking skills when examining labels and concepts like Latino and Latinidad. I learned about the history of the Latinx community in the United States and gained insight into issues like discrimination and assimilation that followed mass migration. I learned about the relevance of music in Latinx culture and thought about the many ways it can be used to express and explore culture.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
Coming into the class, I had some pretty big assumptions about the general content of the class. At first, I didn't think the course was going to center on US Latinx studies; I thought it was
going to focus on the history of Latin American countries and how those become affected by US intervention. Personally, I truly enjoy the direction the course is going. Learning about the history
of Latinos in the US, their struggles, their legacy, is a rich topic that I had previously not had the resources to understand. I've always wanted to learn more about this but I've never really had
the impetus to do so. I think it is so interesting to talk about these historical events, like the Chicano movement or the labor strikes, and tell my friends about them. It's a part of history that
goes unnoticed and it's worthy of bringing up everyone once in a while during a conversation. Outside of that, I feel like this class has made me more conscious of the continual Latino
presence in the US and what people are doing to combat injustice. I've done research and learned about powerful organizations, both in North Carolina and my hometown of Miami. It's
amazing seeing that everywhere there are communities like these all fighting for visibility and justice. I gain a lot from the music component of the course, and connect it to other music classes I've
taken at Duke. It's interesting seeing the connection between how the music we study is composed and what the music is representing. Understanding the Chicano movement through
song is a beautiful way to look at history. A song I particularly found touching was "Urbano's song". It was by far one of the saddest songs I've heard this year, and I still listen to it in my
 spare time.More concisely I learned:
- How to analyze Latino history and research topics in Latino studies.
- How to make a community facing project 
- How service learning can be used to supplement a class as well as engage with the surrounding community.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The structure of this course was fantastic. The homework was very manageable and class time was used effectively. In class, we had the opportunity to practice several mediums of the Spanish language, such as writing, speaking, and listening. The course focused on learning Spanish through our own ideas and interests, and always invited us to learn more. I would keep this course the same in future years, but I would especially keep the time for casual conversation about--for example--our weekend. Similarly, I loved the group projects and activities, even as someone who typically doesn't love group work. My classmates were genuinely engaged in this class. I also enjoyed the 1 hour, 3x a week pace of class.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

Furthermore, Professor Celia is an extremely funny and light-hearted individual, always bringing up the energy of the classroom, even at 8:45 am.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The homework is definitely important for class. You start most classes by reviewing the answers and then you build off of that and get clarification. You will be participating every class, which is really important tio Professor Karahlios. This will improve your speaking skills though. I think the mesa redonda was the most helpful project we did this year. question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I think I will definitely need to keep up on reviewing the different grammatical tenses on a daily basis. I found that with this class, I am using every tense in some way, and it's important that I keep up with the practice and knowledge of the conjugation of these tenses, which is what I had to do in this class. At first, I found the cold calling nerve-racking by our professor for responses but I found that as the semester went on, I felt that these "cold calls" helped promote my confidence in speaking and helped me understand how to correct my sentence structure or grammar. I also appreciated our professor providing us with different resources to prepare for the quizzes. A lot of what we learned in this semester was filled with a lot of grammar and vocabulary and the resources provided really helped me study and prepare for the quizzes.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: This class was one of my favorite classes I have ever taken at Duke. Harry's approach to teaching almost entirely in spanish was indispensable regarding my ability to learn. Having a technology free classroom was also extraordinarily important and should be implemented in every language class. The grammar structures we learned in this class were laid out really well. I also really enjoyed the units from the textbook that we studied, because they were actually interesting and relevant to our time period. I really appreciated how Harry pushed the envelope and encouraged us to express our opinions, while still maintaining a safe and constructive environment, especially during the mujeres y poder chapter. The cold calling and pressure to perform well for a participation grade was great as well. I also liked having lots of grades.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The course was well paced, with quizzes only after we had sufficiently covered a topic. I liked that we started out slower in the beginning of a new topic with vocabulary and general conversation surrounding the topic, before we learned and incorporated the new grammar structures. The graded assignments -- like in-class writings, group projects, and the mesa redondas -- were spread out, which was also good. For the quizzes, the materials provided were very helpful as preparation. I used them a lot. I created my own study guides based on them. The most helpful part of the course was the small group discussions and one-on-one conversations which got me to practice speaking in a lower-stress situation.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I really appreciated that Harry spoke Spanish about 90% of the time during class. It significantly improved my listening comprehension and speaking skills. Looking back on the semester, I can see how much progress I made—I'm much stronger now than I was at the beginning, and I credit a lot of that to the immersive language environment he created.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The main components of the course were completing Interactive Activities in the BLINK Learning Online Textbook (due at the end of every unit), 8 in-class writings, leading a Mesa Redonda (group project where you lecture for 10-12 minutes and lead small-group discussions with your classmates on a specific topic), quizzes at the end of every unit, Boomalang conversations with native speakers, and doing in-class presentations. I really loved the structure of the course because it let us make mistakes and enjoy the learning process without pressure to be perfect all the time, but the in-class writings and impromptu presentations were an amazing opportunity to challenge myself and improve my on the spot thinking in Spanish.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Spanish 204 has been the most well designed and executed course I have taken during my time at Duke (I am finishing up my freshman spring right now). The canvas page for the course is full of helpful resources and instructions, but unlike many of the other classes I have taken here, the page is nicely organized and not overwhelming or oversaturated with redundant information. Course expectations are impeccably clear and the home page on canvas enables you to see exactly what you are expected to complete before coming to class and exactly what you will be expected to do during class. I felt extremely well prepared for every quiz and Harry made sure we knew where to look for extra support/resources if we ever needed nay help preparing for quizzes or other assignments. Although Harry can be a bit sarcastic or sassy at times, he is one of only a few professors who goes above and beyond in ensuring that his students are set up for success as best as possible…and you can tell that he genuinely cares about the well being of his students both within Spanish 204 and beyond. Group projects were a major stressor for me within the course, but I recognize that they were one of the most beneficial tools in improving my speaking skills. The consistency of the course components and expectations made succeeding despite encountering challenges with the content much easier.

My biggest takeaway, and I think the difference between this course and all my previous courses, was the idea of thinking in Spanish rather than thinking in English and translating to Spanish. What I have noticed over that past semester is that through being in this course, this skill of thinking in Spanish has started to come naturally to me. Not only have I significantly improved my in-class writings, but I have also become more fluent when I speak. When I speak in English, which I am fluent in, I do not think about what I say but rather that it just naturally comes out. question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

We always discussed why a particular sentence is worded the way it is and what rules apply to it. Lastly, I realized the importance of having confidence to answer up in class and taking in criticism if and when something you said was wrong. Minimizing stress is not only good for student because we have a million other things to stress about, but it makes us less afraid to fail--a natural and essential part of language learning.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Vocabularies, grammar (reported speech, past conditional, more subjunctives, ways to express emotions, etc), spanish culture and festivals.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I gained better confidence in my language using skills and a better appreciation for learning through making mistakes. Messing up a sentence by spontaneously speaking is more beneficial to my education than obsessing over perfection. I learned more about the mechanics of language and the implied semantics of certain words. Additionally we focused on language patterns, which is something I had never focused on as intensely in my high school Spanish courses. It allowed me to understand how to create a word (noun to adjective to verb form) even if I hadn't technically learned it.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to speak about a subject in a non-biased way, how to learn foundations of another language, and ask questions that go beyond a yes or no side.

response_text: I learned about every part of grammar included in the Spanish language, especially verb tenses. I also learned new vocabulary so that I can speak about more aspects of life. Finally, I learned about specific parts of Hispanic culture in different countries.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I developed public speaking skills, utilizing different verb tenses and structures, and learned how to teach a class.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I improved my Spanish speaking ability and fluidity in speaking, I learned how to think in Spanish rather than English, and I learned how to study better for Spanish.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I think I developed broader confidence in many of the skills I had been taught in previous Spanish courses, but did not trust myself to use. I think my use of presenter-progresivo, futuro, condicional, and subjunctive all increased over the course of the semester. I also think my article errors decreased marginally over the course. My vocabulary expanded as well.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned many new tenses of Spanish verbs and how to conjugate them and apply them into different situations, and I have now learned all of the different verb tenses. I also feel my skills in public speaking in Spanish drastically improved because we participated in many group projects that were prepared in one class period, and we had to present about a topic while using minimal notes, which forced me to learn how to speak freely and fluidly, rather than simply memorizing exactly what to say or translating everything from English to Spanish in my head. I also noticed myself greatly improving in my writing skills because we completed "escrituras" at the end of class every Friday, which are 15-minute writing sessions about a topic we covered in class, and this led me to improve in my ability to write fluidly, similarly to how I had to learn to speak publicly, without having time to translate everything in my head or access to any resources to translate words I didn't know. This allowed me to learn how to use the vocabulary I do have to write a good amount about a topic, even if it is new to me.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Throughout this course I developed new study habits because I discovered that you can't learn a language by studying all at once, but instead, it is super helpful to study a little bit every day. Adjusting to the rigor of this course was what helped me develop new studying habits that I will use in all my language classes and other classes in the future. In this course I developed new knowledge in grammar conjugations and I learned new vocabulary. I was also able to improve my writing through positive and constructive feedback from my professor specifically with fixing conjugations.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The instructor was very engaging and energetic. He came to every class with a passion to teach and he clearly cares for his students. I liked the roundtable discussion, group projects, Kahoots, and the cultural aspects of class.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I think randomly calling on students helped keep me engaged. I also thought the quizzes were fair and covered what we learned well.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: One aspect of the class that facilitated a safe learning environment was the constant opportunity for group learning activities. By providing ways for us to collaborate with our piers, we were able to get to know each other. Whenever we had questions, we had no fears in asking others. When attending an academic institution like Duke, there can be large fears of competition between classmates. This classroom was the exact opposite, characterized by collaboration. In moving forward, group course components such as the "Mesa Redonda" and "Proyectos en Grupo" are essential to keep.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I liked the kahoots, as they were fun interludes on the general pattern of classes. I know there is a general formula that spanish classes at duke have to follow, and within those bounds harry did an excellent job.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Professor Karahalios was great at explaining complicated concepts and functions in a very simple and clear manner, while still making sure he used almost exclusively Spanish while teaching. This was very helpful to me, because it allowed me to gradually come to understand more and more of the things I wouldn't have been able to absorb before this course and learn how to improvise when I was called on and didn't have the vocabulary I needed or know how to convey a point in Spanish the same way I would convey it in English. My favorite course components were our group projects, which we had to prepare with small groups in one day of class and then present to the rest of the class, and the Mesa Redonda project, which was a bigger assignment in which groups of around 4 had about a week to prepare an hour-long presentation of topics and discussion of articles and sources that are sent to the class to study before the discussion. These projects made me much better at verbalizing complex ideas in Spanish on the fly and understanding more complicated ideas that others were trying to get across.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: My professor made the course very interactive and was always very energetic which made class fun and engaging. This helped my learning because I always had to be paying attention and by contributing to group conversation I learned more Spanish. For future years I think that group projects and mesa redondas should be kept because presenting in front of the class without writing down everything I was going to say helped me become a better Spanish speaker. Additionally, I enjoyed when my professor used Kahoots which I think should be kept for next semester because they helped me discover what I needed to spend more time studying.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Mastery of Preterite vs. Imperfect Tenses: I gained a much stronger understanding of when to use the preterite versus the imperfect, which helped me communicate more clearly about past events. Through practice and feedback, I learned to distinguish between completed actions (preterite) and ongoing or habitual actions (imperfect), which is essential for accurate storytelling and conversation.Expressing Impersonality: I learned various grammatical structures used to express impersonal ideas in Spanish. This skill has helped me write and speak in a more academic and formal tone, especially when discussing broader societal topics without referring to a specific subject.Speaking and Debating in the Mesa Redonda: Participating in the mesa redonda improved my ability to express opinions, support arguments, and respond spontaneously in Spanish. It also taught me how to listen actively and engage respectfully in group discussions, which was especially useful during our presentations and debates on current cultural and social issues.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I feel like three specific things I have learned in this class are about the culture of many Spanish speaking countries, proper grammar, and overall improvement in my writing ability in Spanish.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: (1) I personally developed a greater level of fluency when it came to reading and writing in Spanish. For example, throughout the semester, we had to write summaries of news articles. At the start of the course, it took me several hours to write a 2-3 paragraph summary of a short news article, as it had been a couple years since my last Spanish course (junior year of high school.) However, throughout this course, I built greater fluency with reading and writing, and can now summarize an article in the same amount of time as I could in English.(2) Additionally, I learned about writing conventions in Spanish. I'd always been curious about things like how punctuation and other grammar conventions in Spanish work, i.e. whether or not they are the same as in English or not. In this course, I learned how to introduce quotes when writing in Spanish, use commas when writing lists, alongside other conventions; some of these were the same as in English, and others were different.(3) Finally, I've further hones my research skills in Spanish through our final project, a research paper requiring me to read, analyze, and contextualize several sources and build an argument based on these.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned a lot about Spanish grammar, which was a good refresher. The grammar was a complicated way about learning about previously simple rules, but this was good because we went more in depth for things that are typically overlooked (like a lot of rules regarding subjunctive that I had never learned before). We also got better at writing in Spanish, through a large number of writing assignments. Especially at the beginning of the year, we would do almost a writing assignment due per class, of about 300 words or so, which taught me the ability to plan my thoughts and execute what I was going to say in Spanish, composing the piece in a matter of a couple hours. I also learned the importance of communication, since we had two thirty minute conversations in Spanish with an adult living in a Latin American country, which helped improve my speaking skills but also helped me realize that speaking is the most important form of foreign language communication and the thing I need the most work on.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Learned a lot about writing style, grammar, and structuring essays.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I think having us work and discuss in groups was a extremely helpful to my learning in this class. This was allowed me to learn from my peers and strengthen my understanding of concepts as well as my writing skills.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: My learning was facilitated by the writing assignments we would do, including noticieros (reading newspapers from other countries and summarizing articles), foros (reading online sources and crafting a brief argument about a topic), and longer and larger essays that we wrote (one individually, and one with a group). The conversations with adults from Spanish-speaking countries also helped me learn through doing rather than studying. I would keep all of the things that I have mentioned, and while this course is heavy on teaching you how to write over how to speak, read, and understand, that makes sense because the name and purpose of the course is writing in Spanish.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Be sure to put in the work near the start of the semester. Reading articles and writing essays, however short, is extremely tedious at first. question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: I would only take it if you are willing to write a lot in Spanish and spend a decent amount of time writing. It is very manageable and there are some classes where we don't have much homework at all, but there will be other classes where you have a ton. I hope that I learned a lot in terms of Spanish writing, and class time wasn't too stressful. Also, the course it set up and the teacher makes it such that it isn't too hard to get a good grade despite the quantity of work, but your writing is graded on quality (it is just not that strict, which is good). 303 might be a better option if you want an easy class, but if you want a quality Spanish class for learning, this is a good choice.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I really enjoyed the structure of the class. Often times, we would briefly be instructed on a topic in the group, then move to smaller groups, then return to the larger class to share our small group discussions. In a foreign language class, having this opportunity to think through our responses and workshop our ideas into something that we felt comfortable sharing aloud was overwhelmingly valuable. Moreso, in a class that by nature discusses sensitive topics, I think the time in small groups helped us to feel more comfortable with one another when sharing vulnerable ideas, especially in an online environment where connection might otherwise not be so easy. I would genuinely say that I have made friends in this class that I look forward to seeing when I return to campus, and that is something that I would not say from many classes at Duke in general, especially not an online class and one taught primarily in a foreign language. Additionally, the instructor was extremely accessible, checking in with us weekly and encouraging us to schedule brief meetings with him to ensure that we were feeling prepared for success in the class. I really appreciated the way that he clearly cared about all of us and our learning.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Throughout this course, I have learned how to interpret various primary sources such as Spanish texts, videos, plays etc. We have discussed how to further analyze these sources in contrast with the experiences of other individuals living in Spain experiencing racism. My knowledge about how race is viewed within Spanish society, and the implications this has on an individual and their community has increased since joining this class.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Throughout this course I have earned about all the ways in which various cultural productions such as songs, films, advertisements, all can be analyzed and how they can show various forms of racism. I also learned about various authors with different backgrounds and their experiences of racism in Spain. Lastly, I learned about how to look deeper into cultural productions and how to distinguish racist ideologies while also being able to talk about these in Spanish.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1. I learned to analyze cultural products, examining intent, audience, content, background, and reception.
2. I gained deeper insight into the history of Spain, specifically regarding race and immigration.
3. I acquired the vocabulary and language structure to speak about race and racism in Spain.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to critically analyze several different styles of cultural products (documentaries, novels, news articles, etc.), improving my writing skills dramatically over the course of the semester. I also learned a ton about the history of Spanish imperialism, immigration policy, and ongoing challenges with racism against black and Chinese immigrants and their descendants. Lastly, I learned about perceptions of racism that helped me expand beyond a US-centric perspective, and it gave me a great appreciation for the diversity of cultures and perspectives that we have at Duke and in the US as a whole.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Some things that we learned from being in the course were how to think critically in Spanish and how to use things that we learned from outside sources in the classroom. Another thing that we learned was how to develop essays and writings in Spanish when given a specific topic or range of ideas to talk about. But on the other hand, we also learned about how to form our own ideas when given a broad topic to write about various radicalized groups within Spain.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Profe Karahalios brought energy and a positive attitude to class each day. It is evident that he is incredibly passionate about what he teaches and also very knowledgeable about the subject. Throughout the semester, we only scratch the surface of all of the readings and interesting topics that he has knowledge of, but he condenses everything in a way that is thought-provoking and interesting. I liked how organized Profe was, and how structured he made the course, with discussion guides before class to help us digest readings, shorter blog assignments to help us practice writing and speaking Spanish, and longer essays to synthesize different texts we read. He made PowerPoint for each class with key concepts from readings, questions to consider, and applications to previous readings, which really helped me understand class material. Profe took the time to learn about Canvas before the start of the semester and had folders with all of the class readings, assignment discussions, and every possible resource you could need as a student learning Spanish. He genuinely wanted us to succeed, improving both as Spanish speakers and as people. He was also always willing to answer questions after class and provide feedback on how we were doing.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The course facilitated our learning by making us actively engage and participate in class. Sometimes the energy was low and we didn't have much to say, but Profe would always call on us and make us step out of our comfort zone which is something that I think was very beneficial for us to make us engage in the class. The course was structured where we did a lot of things outside of the class and then we came to class to talk about them. I think this structure was nice sometimes, but sometimes it felt repetitive for us to just keep talking about the same thing that we had already learned about on our own, so maybe incorporating some additional videos or readings that we do in class instead of talking about the same ones that we already wrote an essay or discussion post about would be better.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
This course taught me a lot about Spanish but also some more general skills.
The big one for me was working on my presenting skills. I already hate presenting in front of the class, and to do so in Spanish was considerably more challenging and pushed me out of my comfort zone a lot. This ended up being a great challenge, as by the end, I felt really confident in my ability to present and was not nearly as nervous as I used to be, and I know going forward that presentations in English will be much easier. 
I also learned how to critically analyze and view movies and other forms of media, looking at cinematography and the director and their story and more. 
Finally, I significantly improved my Spanish which was really what I was hoping to get out of this.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This course helped me develop a deeper understanding of cultural studies within the context of the Spanish language, and I was challenged to expand my oral, presenting, writing, and discussion skills in Spanish during this course. I also learned to develop an analytical mindset, as we used films to help understand different applications of cultural studies and the Spanish language. Finally, this course helped me learn how to work on problem solving in a group setting, as we had several group projects that helped me apply my Spanish speaking and writing skills while also solving problems related to cultural studies.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This was my first language class at Duke, and I think that I was able to develop my textual analysis skills and more of an understanding of Spanish as a language. I also learned so much about evaluating different forms of racial biases, and I'm coming out of this class ready to extend this perspective to a global lens.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I feel like I learned a LOT. Beyond purely improving my Spanish speaking and writing skills, I learned how to write stronger essays through Synthesis Essays. These Synthesis Essays were very manageable and were about the units we learned from before. I learned how to view various forms of art like images, commercials, essays, books, and autobiographies that were mainly in Spanish. Lastly, I was able to gain confidence through speaking in Mesa Redondas, in-class small group discussions, that helped me build my quick thinking skills.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

I have a much greater insight into how cultures exist in incredibly monocultural societies. While the US is certainly not without problems, this course has taught me to appreciate that the incredible diversity of this country is absolutely paramount towards successful progress and that in more monocultural societies it is incredibly difficult for marginalized people to find any representation at all from their home.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Three things that I developed/learned during the course had to do with the Latino/poc community. I learned about the cultural competence and how its important for people who are trying to go into the medical field because everyone needs to be treated with respect and sometimes working with people from different backgrounds may need for different handling techniques. I also learned about the need for interpreters and translators. Finally, I also learned about the need to speak other languages other than English especially in this ever-growing country.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned that acting out of your comfort zone can sometimes be very helpful to other people and although some questions may seem intrusive, they are actually very beneficial to learning about people and their lifestyles. I also learned that cultural competence is not only learning to speak another language but engaging in that culture and that culture mastery can never be achieved. Lastly, I learned that a person in Latina America is in fact, American and that this term should not be used for only those in the United States.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Specifically, I learned about the extent and dynamics of food insecurity in the country, and especially in North Carolina and Durham. I learned new vocabulary and correcting common grammatical errors that I was making. I also learned about many different service organizations both locally and nationally (such as TCG, Iglesia Emanuel, Root Causes, etc...) that worked to address social determinants of health.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned to speak more fluent and conversational Spanish through various modalities inside and outside the classroom. I learned more about the general health disparities that Latine persons face inside and outside of the United States, through various theories/frameworks but also personal stories from communities. Lastly, I learned how these health topics were related to the Latine population in Durham through engaging in and reflecting on service learning with the Latine community.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned about social determinants of health from the Latino and immigrant perspectives. I learned about how where you live impacts the food you have access to and the amount of daily stress you are under from violence or lack of public parks. I also learned about the immigrant paradox and potential explanations for why recently immigrated Latinos are healthier than Latinos who have been in the US for longer. I also learned about service learning and the value of learning about complex issues alongside actual community engagement.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: There was a good balance of lectures, small-group discussions, essays, and quizzes. I felt as though the first portion of the semester was a bit lecture-heavy, but I enjoyed the latter half where we engaged in discussions over materials. I felt like these discussions helped me learn about the material, but they were also more helpful for me regarding my Spanish-speaking skills. I think I'd keep the small group discussions for future years because I found them really helpful and engaging.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The multiple presentation activities were really helpful in helping build my confidence in using my Spanish skills in an academic setting. The service learning portion also helped me build confidence using Spanish in real life interactions.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Dr. Clifford was very patient and flexible with each student. I felt insecure about my Spanish skills in the beginning, but Dr. Clifford was very encouraging. I also enjoyed that the course was very conversational and interesting. We learned about different concepts through different mediums everyday; it wasn't just a lecture every class period.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Joan was forgiving with deadlines and was willing to help in whatever way she could to ensure it was feasible for her students to get their work done. The course prioritized learning the content more so that the final grade which I believe is a good attribute in a class of pre-meds/Global Health/PubPol majors who are aiming to learn how to provide better care or create better polices to improve healthcare outcomes. Joan did a great job covering the complexities of Latino health in America from urban and rural struggles, ACEs, exclusion because of documentation status, mental health, determinants of health, holistic health, and so much more in a way that was understandable in another language, giving us a deep understanding of this community.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Joan facilitated learning by mixing up assignments; this class has a little of everything so as not to bore students with the same format all year round. My final project is a podcast and I really loved interviewing people and taking the time to connect with the community on what we learned - this would not have been possible without a professor willing to promote students' interests.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: A good amount of the partner organizations work on the weekends or during regular class hours so there may be some conflicts if you have a lot of classes back to back or commitments on the weekends. So, be prepared to manage a long term service commitment around this -- that is have a plan before taking the course that also accommodates your other projected semester commitments (and some wiggle room for unexpected events) to make sure you are able to enjoy that aspect of the class and doesn't become a point of stress.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: This course is a little bit drier in the beginning, but it is because there are more readings and lectures to get a foundational understanding of the material that will be discussed throughout the course. Once halfway through the course, it is more about application of that learned knowledge, so it becomes more creative and more fun. The service learning portion also made the course a lot more meaningful and engaging because you are getting the change to directly interact with the community in a way that matters; this engagement also made me want to engage more in the course material so I could apply it in the service learning portion.

response_text: In this course I learned the challenges and the barriers that confront the Latino community in the US and Latin American countries. We also constructed and discussed different health policy interventions that can improve Latino health in the US.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned to speak more fluent and conversational Spanish through various modalities inside and outside the classroom. I learned more about the general health disparities that Latine persons face inside and outside of the United States, through various theories/frameworks but also personal stories from communities. Lastly, I learned how these health topics were related to the Latine population in Durham through engaging in and reflecting on service learning with the Latine community.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned about social determinants of health from the Latino and immigrant perspectives. I learned about how where you live impacts the food you have access to and the amount of daily stress you are under from violence or lack of public parks. I also learned about the immigrant paradox and potential explanations for why recently immigrated Latinos are healthier than Latinos who have been in the US for longer. I also learned about service learning and the value of learning about complex issues alongside actual community engagement.

We also constructed and discussed different health policy interventions that can improve Latino health in the US.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: You should definitely do it. Costa Rica is an amazing place. You'll gain new life perspective and learn a lot. If you decide to come, commit to having a positive attitude and an open mind; it makes all the difference, and you'll enjoy your time much more.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Take it if you want to experience day-to-day life in another culture! Don't expect luxury accommodations, and prepare yourself to be flexible and adapt to a different way of life.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: I would highly encourage any student wanting to take this class to do so. To get the most out of it, however, all students need to come with an open mind, be prepared to encounter slight discomfort, and be willing to engage with lots of new people and work in teams.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

- more environmentally conscious ways of daily living
- super interesting range of speakers
- many wonderful recipes
- the health care system in Costa Rica

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I developed my spanish speaking skills, my ability to be open to other cultures and experiences, and my presentation skills.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned more about family life in Costa Rica, how to speak Spanish more conversationally, and about many of the different cultures that exist in Costa Rica

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Spanish interpreting and speaking skills. I learned intercultural competence and important insight into acclimating to and respecting the lives of other cultures.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned about the culture and healthcare system of Costa Rica, as well as how to engage and be immersed in a new culture and country. I also developed my Spanish skills through immersion and living with a host family that did not speak any English.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned a lot about the Costa Rican healthcare system, I learned to be more patient and push myself out of my comfort zone, and I learned a lot about different indigenous groups and different cultural aspects of Costa Rica as well.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to communicate effectively and appropriately in a culturally competent way. Especially when we are entering houses of our host families, entering indigenous communities, and other culturally related areas. It is important to be effective and appropriate, avoiding biases.I learned how to navigate language barriers through methods of explaining around the topic, using hand or facial expressions. While I am a native speaker, I struggle with more advanced and academic words. Therefore, being an environment where Spanish is the native language was helpful in expanding my fluidity and comprehension.The skills I learned through this course was navigating a culture through curiosity and ambition. Without those two characteristics it would be difficult to have a full immersion into the culture, traditions, and families.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to live in another country and adapt to a different culture! My Spanish skills developed rapidly in this completely immersive environment, and I became much more confident in conversing with fluent speakers. I also improved at living in the moment, really taking in each day as a new adventure and opportunity for learning.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Some of the things that we learned were speaking in Spanish and living our daily lives while speaking in Spanish and living in a Spanish speaking country. We learned about cultural incompetence and putting ourselves in the shoes of other people and respecting their cultures. We also learned about how to live in the moment and respect other people. We also learned about health care systems in Costa Rica and how they are different than the ones that we have in the United States.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I think that the mix of excursions and class time was the best structure for my personal learning. Class time never exceeded 3 hours and it was always engaging. I also love the way we has fun excursions planned into our programming so that we could learn about the culture of Costa Rica first hand outside of the classroom.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Our professor was an awesome role model for how to show respect to and interest in learning about so many different aspects of Costa Rica, and I'm thankful that she pushed us to explore outside of our comfort zones (in a low pressure way) to learn about different cultures, foods, dances, words, speak more Spanish in our every day activities even if we knew it wasn't perfect, and ask questions about health, society, daily life, new words, and language to our families. Also, Profe's flexibility with planning to make sure we could have all of our charlas was incredibly kind, and her ability to gauge our energy levels made the month feel more do-able. The clear plan for when students had medical problems and addition of our guide, Julio, were also critical to the good flow and feelings of safety/everyone being on the same page

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Profe's cheerfulness and genuine desire to help us slowly master the Spanish language was super fun and inspiring. I like the short morning classes and daily activities after. To see new places around Costa Rica and try new foods was stimulating and helped us learn many new frases and vocabulary.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The professor was constantly looking to help her students in any way she could. Nearly everything I would keep for future years.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I liked how we had different guest speakers come in and talk to us, because they had specific expertise that was interesting to hear about as opposed to hearing things more secondhand. I particularly liked the charla from Rebecca talking about reproductive rights, so I would definitely keep that talk. I also liked the different activities we did on the mindfulness day such as yoga and painting.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Professor Bethzaida ensured that everyone was fully involved and interacted even when it seemed scary to try at first. Keeping that student and teacher relationship created further facilitation for community growth and having a circle of support.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Profe's enthusiasm for this course and life in general is what makes this course so incredible! I feel that all the aspects of this course were perfectly balanced, between presentations, ticotoks, and reflections. I really appreciate that Profe puts a large emphasis on engagement in the course in your grade, and I think this helps students stay focused and self reflect throughout the course. It is clear that the most important element of this course for Profe is our individual learning.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Learning was facilitated by the weekly homework assignments and the time that we spent engaging with the community and learning about different customs of Costa Rica. Also by living in the houses with the Host Moms , we learned a lot about daily lives of how they lived and worked. Some things that should be kept are the excursions that we went on and some of the overnight trips, they were really impactful and it gave more of vacation than class when we went on the excursions. I think this is important because it didn't feel like we were stuck in a class room the whole time but rather we were able to live in the country that we were actually living in.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: One of the most stimulating parts of the class was the guest speakers that came into class because while we had material to prepare us for class, guest speakers are unpredictable so making sure to really pay attention to pick up as much as we could from those "charlas" was one of the most stimulating parts of the course for me.

our group size and closeness
