question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: I think that the class was adequately stimulating.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The element of always having something new to do, whether it be an excursion or a new class topic was always fun and kept everyone engaged, especially hikes and visits to places where we could be active.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The way learning was incorporated into every part, and the way we learned about different topics every day made the course very stimulating because we were always learning something new, although relevant. I think the only thing that could be done is maybe for some of the charlas, have them be more interactive but I don't know if that's possible because I think each lecturer brings their own style and it may be more of our job to find ways to appreciate the information being presented (and the manner in which it is being presented).

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: This class was extremely fun because everybody wanted to be here in Costa Rica, wanted to learn spanish, and wanted to get the most out of the program. Most people were extroverts which made the experience ten times better as conversation in spanish would flow without fear of constantly making mistakes. It was stimulating to talk with Ticotokers (los Ticos) because they were young and patient and helped us with our spanish greatly.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The class size was small and everyone was wanting to learn and grow in our Spanish skills. We were immersed into a new culture in which we were forced to be out of our comfort zone, talking in Spanish, trying new foods, and engaging in different daily activities.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: Profe was always having us do a bunch of different activities in class that made it intellectually stimulating because it wasn't just a straight lecture for the 3 hour class window. However, I will say I could have been a little bit more intellectually stimulated if we had more than one 5 minute break during this three hour window because the longest courses that I have taken at Duke are 2 and a half hours, and they always have a 15 min break. So for a 3hr/3hr 15 min class I think 2 10 min breaks or 3 5 min breaks would be appreciated.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The excursions outside of Turrialba were full immersions culturally and linguistically. Everyday it was a new topic that we would further expand and explain. Each day was a new adventure and day of learning. Which facilitated an environment of excitement and a stimulating learning environment.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: Every moment I was in this course I was learning something - whether about Spanish, myself, my peers, or Costa Rica! This course is a very involved month of learning.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: Some things that made the course stimulating was our excursions to indigenous communities and learning about how they do things and comparing it to things that we have in the United States.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Do it! This is such an amazing opportunity and if you have time to do it, I think you definitely should. If you're even considering this course in the slightest, I recommend you do it and don't let your worries about how good your Spanish is hold you back. The point of immersion is to improve your language skills so allow yourself to take that opportunity :)

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Absolutely go for it!! If you are able to come, you will not regret it!

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Take it! One of the most immersive and enjoyable courses that Duke has to offer because it was very stimulating.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned a lot about the immigration system in the United States, particularly about how difficult it is to receive citizenship in the United States. I also learned about ELS programs, particularly in North Carolina and how they are often inadequate. This class taught me to think about systemic issues and poor allocation of funding regarding education and immigration of Latin Americans.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Watching film and reading articles in Spanish, laws about immigration, and how the educational system works for english language learners

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I developed my communication skills and vocabulary. Furthermore, I learned a lot about the US education and immigration systems and historic policy rulings.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Spanish speaking, writing, and listening abilities.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: New grammar and vocab related to education and immigration, interesting laws and history of immigration in the U.S., different education structures in the U.S>

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned a lot about different types of ESL models, barriers for immigrants, the system of becoming a citizen in the United States, and how the pandemic impacted education for immigrants in the United States.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I developed more critical thinking skills. I learned how to translate what I was thinking into Spanish so I could communicate in the target language. I also was able to bounce between the two languages effectively especially when we had to read something in English but speak about it in Spanish. Lastly, I learned how to have purposeful discussions with peers.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
-I learned about the challenges immigrant youth experience in the education system in the context of the Durham community.
-I learned about different forms of language education models in the United States.
-I learned about the school to deportation pipeline, farmworker youth, and deported individuals.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: We went more in depth about the effects that immigration has on education, not just as students but also as professors and parents. We also learned about laws and issues that have affected immigrants since the US became its own country, and I found this really interesting because you can truly see how little by little, diversity is a little more celebrated in this country now than it was decades ago. question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: One insight I gained during the class was the cultural impact of being Latino on different systems here in the United States. A good example of this is the fact that many Latino people do not question authority because they think a doctor knows better than them, leading to potential misdiagnoses. Because I am considering a job in the healthcare field, this insight is something I can help change (i.e. encouraging Latinx patients to speak up about their experiences). Similarly, I also learned how to better engage a class in a group discussion. For instance, the Mesa Redonda taught me the importance of using a thought provoking question (i.e. why a white person cast in a Latinx role is considered progressive, but not vice versa). Finally, I also learned how to better engage with the community. I was quite shy and stayed in my Duke bubble before this course, afraid to do things such as reach out to local restaurant owners. Being obligated to do so in this class exposed me to a wide variety of pillars of the Durham community, such as Boricua, which helps maintain a safe space for Black/Latinx people in Durham and support the most vulnerable (i.e. those in subsidized housing).

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned more about the Latinx culture in Durham, expanded my speaking skills, and learned a lot from talking to individuals about their experiences.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This class was honestly amazing because we got to interact with the Latino community which meant that we got to practice our Spanish with native Spanish speakers. We learned a lot of things about the Durham community that is relevant to everyday life, and I learned a lot about the community around me.

3. I learned about various Latino artists who have gained immense popularity.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I loved going on outings into the Durham community. For instance, going to the Iglesia was quite inspiring, because I was able to see not only how powerful the Latino community is (e.g. having such a large church made up of gold and crosses), but how loving and accepting there are (i.e. hugging everyone there, regardless of if they were familiar or not). Similarly, I also think that the class discussions done related to the content generally went quite well. I enjoyed the fact that we would first discuss our ideas in small groups before moving into a larger group discussion, allowing us to collect our ideas or the main takeaways we had from the video before beginning to discuss to a larger group. I also liked that the course had service learning, as it helped us apply what we learned in class to a broader context (e.g. applying the knowledge we have of Latino children in American schools and their disadvantages coming from another family to the learning delays we may see from them in class).

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The instructor absolutely facilitated my learning by allowing us to have time to discuss with other individuals in the class and get comfortable with the other classmates. In a class that is small and of this size, it felt very intimate and I got to know the other students very well. I certainly think the small group conversations should continue to be utilized in the future. Something else that I enjoyed was being able to "prepare" for each class. That way, nothing we had to speak about was something we had not yet studied or read about. It made conversations flow.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: thought the course was very stimulating, guest speakers and visits made what we learned in the classroom come to life

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: I feel what made this class intellectually stimulating was having to describe complicated and complex phenomenons in a second language. Take, for example, the concept of a "reflected image", or that immigrants start to believe the representations they see of themselves in the media constantly. The idea is complicated, relating to psychology concepts such as the self-fulfilling prophecy. Expressing it in English was already difficult. Giving such examples of the concept in Spanish, and using more limited vocabulary to explain the impact on an immigrant child's psyche was even more difficult. It was a challenge not just in elocution in a second language, but in learning to create clear ideas that translate well across languages.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: I would advise this student to be prepared to make a significant time commitment to the class, from being part of service learning projects every week, to constantly having to do preparation assignments, to heading out into the Durham community every few weeks, to even having to do their own independent project related to Latinos in Durham. However, I would also explain to them that the commitment is worth, not only in terms of bettering their use in Spanish, but also increasing their awareness of the different Latino efforts they can support (i.e. local markets in La Pulga) and challenges in the Latino community they can advocate for (i.e. better healthcare for migrant workers). I would also let them know that the professor is extremely kind and caring, and her generosity (i.e. driving with students that need a ride to community events) makes the class feel like fun!

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: She was present, but she never answered her emails. It took forever to get a response and she was never consistent in her instruction. So many times I felt confused in the class and there was a serious lack of structure to the course. There was also not a very specific guide or rubric for our presentations. It was so general and then I received an arbitrary grade and had no idea what that was based on.  Communication was really bad and overall needs to be improved, because you can't lead a class and have students feel so unsure and confused 90% of the time. And then when we send emails to ask for clarification she didn't respond.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: There was a lot of small group discussion before sharing to the whole class. Dra. Evinson also shared a lot of outside-of-class activities and talks that we could engage in to learn more. I really enjoyed a lot of the texts that we read/watched, and I felt like they were the perfect amount where I typically didn't feel overwhelmed by the reading and I was able to complete it all.

response_text: This class is a great advanced Spanish course whether you're a first-year or a fourth-year, or a Spanish major/minor or just someone looking to fulfill their language requirement. question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Its very interesting and teaches you about history - and more modern issues - but be wary if your spanish level isnt VERY high because it can be difficult otherwise.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: You need to be very comfortable understanding rapid Spanish to understand this professor. As a non-native speaker, this was a bit of a hurdle at first.I will be so honest, I dreaded coming to this class. It felt like a waste of time for the most part. I felt like we spent time over analyzing things that did not need to be read into so deeply. I do think some people found this course interesting and meaningful but the content personally the most fascinating for me. As a Spanish major, I enjoy the cultural and community building aspect of other courses more than this one, as the discussion felt stuffy and obnoxious at times.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I improved my ability to read in Spanish, as well as my ability to analyze texts in general. I also feel that my writing skills improved significantly as a result of the course.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Specifically, I learned how to manage my work wisely. The class involved a lot of reading and writing, so I had to become familiar with how to manage my time between weekly readings and the writing assignments that we had to write.As it would turn out, my first college "paper" was actually in this Spanish class, so it wasn't even in my primary language. Writing this 1,000 word Spanish paper really helped me develop both writing and phrasing skills that I have been able to apply to all my other assignments, and has advanced my style of writing greatly.Finally, the class taught me the importance of participation. Professor Mulligan made it clear that being present mindfully in class was crucial to understanding the themes and work-load that we had to handle. Speaking up and asking questions was the best way to engage, and listening to your peers when they had interventions was the most efficient way of relating to them and maybe realize some aspects of the material you wouldn't have realized initially.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1. Academic and professional writing skills in Spanish
2. Argument structures for humanities research
3. Trends in modern Latin American literature

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Practiced pulling examples from multiple different literary texts to formulate a cohesive argument. Gained more insight on how historical context affects literature. Read critical academic essay and used it as part of my critical analysis.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to write academically in Spanish, actively interact with Spanish texts, and construct arguments and theories around a text.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned critical tools for understanding literature in the Spanish language. I also practiced writing weekly in Spanish in Discussions, replied to other Peer comments, and monthly papers. I learned how to interpret abstract/baroque/ literary styles.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This was one of my first humanities course where I was required to read lengthy excerpts every week in order to be prepared for class. I developed strategies that allowed me to skim these readings in depth so I did not lose much information, but also how to read such long and intellectual works in another language. Furthermore, this class taught me about the syntax and grammar of Spanish when writing in it.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I broadened my knowledge of Spanish literature. It challenged me a lot because as a native speaker I use conversational Spanish and academic Spanish takes a lot more attention to grasp and writing essays in a different language is a skill I happily acquired in this course.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I had never written any formal papers in Spanish before, nor had I engaged with Spanish language literature. For me, this course was a crash-course in learning how to analyze and write about Spanish language literature. I also learned more about surrealism, barroquism, and existentialism.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I think I learned a lot about writing in generally and how to answer essay prompts in a way that doesn't only answer the question, but actually constructs a prompt and introduces thought-provoking questions. I also learned a lot about connections between Latin American histories and the literature produced in response to certain events. I also feel that through practice and immersion, my skills in Spanish, specifically writing and reading, have improved tremendously.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: In this course, I've been able to develop my Spanish writing skills. Through discussions and papers, Professor Mulligan gave constructive feedback that allowed me to improve my writing. Also, I like the clear structure of the course because I'm able to be fully prepared for each course. There's usually a reading before class, we discuss during class (seminar style), do question interventions, and have discussions once a week. This helped me stay on top of my coursework and overall I think it helped improve my comprehension of the course.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
I feel that it helped with my time management through the readings. 
I learned about different authors and see new viewpoints from Latin America and Spain.
I learned (somewhat) how to interpret and understand literary theory in Spanish.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I was able to develop better critical thinking skills in regards to writing spanish papers for this class. I also learned many interesting facts about the way literature was wrote in the 1900s eras and the history of what this type on non-realistic or fantasy literature.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to write academic responses in Spanish and read Spanish literature.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Professor Mulligan is a very good teacher who encourages discussion in his classes. I really enjoyed the format the class was taught in, with lectures, discussions, and weekly discussion board posts. I also thought the works we read were very interesting and showed the true variability of Spanish literature.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

I gained confidence and improved my abilities in writing and speaking of Spanish.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: First off, I have developed a greater knowledge on the history of governance and social movements in Spain and some Latinamerican countries. I think this helped to be able to have a deeper analyses of the text and videos we dived into throughout the course. I also learned of techniques to look beyond the surface level of readings. For example, thinking of how an autobiography may shift depending on when an author decides to tell their story; what do they want to communicate? Lastly, I learned to be specific within my arguments in the essays produced. While I may touch on broad topics, I learned to apply to a specific case study or time period to validate the argument.

course: SPANISH-331S-01 : INTRO LIT FILM POPULAR CULTURE.SPANISH-331S-01.
question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I really enjoyed the way we worked on essays. The timing for the essays was appropriate and I liked the hands-on approach with the workshops we had in class. This was a nice change of pace, as in other classes it seems like professors assign essays and never talk about them - expecting us students to nail the topic without engaging in conversation. course: SPANISH-331S-01 : INTRO LIT FILM POPULAR CULTURE.SPANISH-331S-01.

course: SPANISH-331S-01 : INTRO LIT FILM POPULAR CULTURE.SPANISH-331S-01.
question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I think the author helped facilitate my overall learning by inspiring discussion of the texts/films throughout the course. For example, by discussing in class how "Madres paralelas" had overarching themes of motherhood in two different stories, I was able to apply this analysis to another film we studied ("Roma") by looking at the overarching themes of abandoning women between the two characters of varying classes. For future years, I would continue the parts of class where we work in groups to try and analyze texts and share our findings, as it helped me synthesize what we read. I also think the structure of the homework (i.e. reflecting on the author's context, considering the plot structure, etc.) helped aid this analysis.

course: SPANISH-331S-01 : INTRO LIT FILM POPULAR CULTURE.SPANISH-331S-01.
question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: What made this class intellectually stimulating was constantly thinking about how the texts we read and analyzed had a deeper meaning. For instance, when I would read a part of a text that confused me (which was often, given if it was in a second language), I would spend time thinking about why the author might have made the choice they did. A good example is the comic "La pesadilla de Obi" - I spent a lot of time reflecting on why the author choosed to have overarching plot devices such as Obi's testicular cancer, and include elements such as Obi exploring both heaven and hell. I also think this class was intellectually stimulating when it came time to write essays. For example, I read a lot of fascinating articles on how Ana Maria Matute constantly reflected on loss of childhood innocence while writing my essay for "Pecado de omisión".

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Throughout this course, we examined so many different forms of media.  We looked at visual art from the Renaissance and Baroque periods, written historical records, first-hand accounts of colonial encounters, contemporary art and photography, and so much more.  In turn, I learned how to interpret diverse historical and cultural artifacts/accounts (art, literature, photography, historical accounts, etc.) and derive meaning and connections in order to paint a comprehensive representation of history.  I also learned how to contextualize materials with social, cultural, and historical information.  For many of the sources we read, we actually did a sort of verbal critical discourse analysis in which we examined the author's biases, certain problematic elements, and harmful historical narratives, many of which related to the colonial project and the erasure of indigenous cultures.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: My Spanish writing improved a ton, as did my Spanish speaking, and I learned a lot about modern literary criticism.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: This classroom environment was so productive and educational, and this is entirely thanks to Professor Rosa.  His lessons are so fortified with external sources, ranging from visual art to first-hand historical accounts, all of which are extremely pertinent to our class discussions.  Professor Rosa always seems to have the perfect source or piece of supplementary material to enhance and deepen our class discussion, and fuel stimulating dialogue.  One of my favorite things about Professor Rosa that characterizes his class environment is his ability to continuously stoke the fire of any class discussion.  Even when he asks a challenging question and no students have an answer, he never shows any frustration with his students whatsoever, but instead continues the conversation himself, and gives is new and interesting ideas to consider.  He never loses his momentum, and helps his students to engage in complex discussions through his offering of countless ideas, thought-provoking questions, and unique perspectives.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: I really liked the wide variety of sources we were presented regarding colonization of the Americas. We had sources made by colonizers, priests, indigenous people, mestizo individuals, black people in Hispaniola, modern-day academics and others. This wide range of sources allowed me to get a good idea of how many perspectives and elements that there were regarding the colonization of the Americas. I definitely learned a lot through the sources we had, and I would keep them for future classes. I do wish we had more of an opportunity to present our ideas in different ways by switching out the "trabajo semanal" writing assignments every once in awhile with something else.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to analyze historical primary sources, improve my knowledge of Latin American history, and learn about trends in political movements.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: The course taught me how to better contextualize political and historical rhetoric in the Latin American context. Additionally, I was introduced to a great length of Latin American history, specifically for Peru, Cuba, and Venezuela. Finally, I learned a lot about how different political ideologies went on to shape the governments of the three aforementioned countries. More in detail, the discussion in the course centered around how the concept of nationhood was built in all three countries, with a special emphasis on Cuba and Venezuela.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: One of the core skills I developed in this course was how to read and analyze texts in Spanish. I had never had the opportunity to engage with college-level texts in Spanish, so even though there was an initial learning curve, by the end of the semester I felt comfortable doing it. A central method was to evaluate history from several different academic perspectives, whether it be through primary-source analysis, historiography, decolonial theory, among others.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I developed a higher level of political analysis that went beyond listening to the everyday political discourse to appreciating the historical elements that influence it. The most important concepts I learned are myths and how they are used in politics such as the Golden Age and Messianism, ideologies as ways to interpret reality to serve a political purpose, and apply them to nation building processes in Perú, Venezuela, and Cuba.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I developed my Spanish writing and speaking skills. I am a native speaker and I have notably seen my Spanish become better, both in the way I speak and better vocabulary and grammar. The professor also very interesting introduced material and learning how to interact with primary sources in a new way.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to analyze primary sources, how to improve spanish writing skills

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Given that the readings were difficult, especially since they were in my second language, I feel that I improved my reading comprehension skills. I feel like this can be measured by the speed at which I completed the assigned readings at the beginning of the semester versus at the end of the semester. A reading that would take me about 4 hours to dissect in the beginning would now take me about an hour. I also learned how to analyze primary sources and extract important details from them while relating them to the context of the history that was occurring at the time. Lastly, I learned how to connect different times of history and the events that happened in them to each other and think of ways that they connect and overlap to point out historical patterns.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I think one of the main things I was able to develop within the length of the course was my Spanish speaking ability as well as my capability to read more complex articles. I think as a native speaker, one assumes the ability to be able to communicate as a given and maybe even something they are proud of. However, I think respect should be given to not only the class but the people within the course as well. There was a specific student from UNC that I think motivated to be more engaged in the class and do my best to communicate my thoughts in a more eloquent manner. I also learned how to analyze and use primary resources within my work.

This course also cultivated a desire to speak more often to people who hold conflicting opinions to my own.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The learning environment was very welcoming and interactive. The class operated in a seminar style, which made it easy to engage in profound class discussions which dissected the course content. The professor helped facilitate discussion by encouraging us to speak, breaking down class content, and asking provocative questions about the reading material. This class made me fond of the seminar style classroom. As such, I aim to take more classes of this nature.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The class was discussion-based, and everyone was encouraged to participate. Every week, one or two students would have to give an interlocution on the readings for that day, which was an interesting way to learn about how other students approached the readings and what their analysis of it was. For each module, there was an interactive project, like a map or a timeline, which provided an additional opportunity to learn through "doing" instead of simply taking notes from a lecture.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The instructor was very amenable and kind, which made the overall learning experience more engaging. Professor Mulligan is very approachable and is always willing to help us with assignment questions and shares information about events happening on campus that are related to the class. The paper worksheets and the emails he sends at the beginning of the week really helped me keep track of where we are in the course and organize the information to study.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The instructor of the course made the class very interactive. Professor Mulligan gave us the freedom to ask him and the class questions whenever needed and he would encourage our classmates to help us with the question. Not only did this help the overall class dynamic, but it also kept us accountable to keep up with the information because our participation was vital. Professor Mulligan also gave us outlines of the day's discussion which was a class program that had all the important details from the reading. This not only helped us focus on the important topics, but it also kept us on pace and made sure that we touched on all the topics before the end of class. Lastly, Professor Mulligan also implemented interventions that kept us accountable and ensured that we had a good grasp on the readings' information.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

I also believe that going through the points touched upon on the reading as well as emphasize the fragility or not full validity of some of the articles we were given got us to develop critical thinking skills--and not blindly believe everything we read as human flaw exists.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

response_text: Professor Mulligan created discussion plans and would hand those out before we began class. This handout outlined some of the key takeaways from a reading that he would want to cover, but in no way limited the scope of our discussion. Often, these sheets served as a launching point for the class to ask our own questions and allowed us to take the conversation in a completely new direction. question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: I think it's a really interesting course but definitely make sure you have good writing and reading comprehension skills in spanish because the readings are LONG and they are DENSE. If you actually want to be able to participate you'll have to spend a lot of time on the readings. However, prof. Mulligan is genuinely one of the sweetest and most understanding people and is always super willing to give extensions or provide additional help if you need it. He always offers to meet outside of class in order to help you better understand assignments or just talk more. He provides a lot of support which makes it much easier.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Take it! It might be challenging at first, especially if Spanish is not your first language or if you struggle with it. However, if you are interested in the content of the class, you will be fine as long as you work hard!

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: I would say that the professor is very engaging and demonstrates clear enthusiasm for the Course when he is not tired. Not his issue, although it was a bit concerning on my part to see a professor clearly tired sometimes. It was only a visual thing not a behavior thing as he still went through class in an educative manner. The life of a humanities professor is not so easy. Aside from the professor, the content is very informative and engaging although if you're unfamiliar with politics it takes a lot of searches to find the foundations of some of the topics mentioned. For example, prior to my college life, I used to be an ignorant individual who wished no relations to politics and have had no interest in history for the most part. However, if you put the effort in and break down the complexity of the readings, you will learn a lot. For the readings, if you find them too difficult, I would recommend reading it once in Spanish and then translating the denser parts to English, read that, and then go back to re read the page. This was very helpful to me since some of the terminology was too complex at times for me too fully understand the undertones of the text rather than the general messages--a nuance you have to consider a lot when dealing with politics. I would also promote speaking when you get the chance and have no fear of making mistakes. Often, when some of the native speakers talk it seems as if they have a vast understanding of the topic but they are stating their answers in a simple manner but their fluency makes it seem more than it is. (not that they weren't, it just exudes this air of being more knowledgeable when really, what they say is quite simple and not so complex).

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: I would say that they should have an interest in politics and government set ups in order to stay engaged in this class.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: If Spanish is not your first language, the material and the assignments will be challenging, but it is worth the extra effort. Professor Mulligan does a great job of creating an environment where everyone's voice can be heard, so don't hesitate to speak up when you have any insight to share. However, I would also encourage you to practice deep and engaged listening (not just listening to formulate a response) when your classmates are talking. Professor Mulligan will propose thought-provoking questions and guide insightful conversations and I encourage you to listen to all there is to be learned from your classmates sharing their personal lived experiences as they relate to the course.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned a lot of new Spanish vocabulary relating to sociolinguistics and social justice for subordinated indigenous languages. I also learned the skill of reading scholarly linguistics articles carefully and attentively. Finally, I learned more about the landscape, specifically in Peru, of the legislation and general attitude in politics around indigenous languages.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
Throughout this course, I learned the following:
1) Knowledge about the intersection between linguistic diversity and human rights, in the context of several Spanish-speaking countries and in environments like academia, the workplace, the law, social settings and more
2) Knowledge about the various representations of linguistic discrimination and injustice, and how this affects a variety of communities
3) Knowledge about the history of linguistic rights in various countries, including the development of legislation and projects/movements to support linguistic human rights

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned a lot about the history of Cuban slavery and migration, the slave trade,  the history of networks of migration from different parts of Spain and Europe to the Americas, the Spanish Civil War, and what it means to be an exile. I improved my Spanish reading comprehension and writing skills. I also improved critical thinking skills when crafting essays about broad topics.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned about a sample of the different pathways and cultural experiences of migration in the Spanish-speaking world in the 19th and 20th centuries and how those migrations affected the migrants, the host country, and the place of emigration. I learned about how to express complex ideas about class, society, and academic theory in a professional and academic manner in the Spanish language. I learned about theories of class can be applied and examined in the real world through the stories and lives of migrants.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Prepare yourself to read 19th century legal documents in Spanish! Not for the faint of heart. But if you're willing to put in the work of deciphering difficult readings, it's an interesting course that covers experiences of migration in Latin America and Spain from the 19th and 20th centuries. Don't expect a close study of a particular time period or place, but a broad survey across geographies and time periods.

The magnitude of population movements across the past 3-4 centuries

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1) How to read and analyze Spanish-based text from a variety of genres (historical, philosophical, political science)
2) Why it is important to realize the greater factors that impact and cause migration and exiles, especially for populations that are marginalized
3) How marginalized populations occupy their positions and what forces lead to this type of societal structuring.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned a lot about the theory of migration with an eye towards Cuba and Latin America more broadly. 1) Application of theory towards the understanding of migration; 2) a history of migration to Latin America; 3) the conflicts and contradictions of the lives of migrants, refugees, and political exiles in the world.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
Three facts I learned were: 
1) Most of the enslaved people coming into Spanish colonies during the 1500-1700s were detained and sold by Catalan slave traders
2) Exilied Spanish Republican soldiers helped the French fight of the Nazis, and were often put in concentration camps as prisoners of war
3) The International Brigade was a group of soldiers that came to defend the Second Spanish Republic from other countries

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

Additionally, I developed my capability to research a more curated view even with a complex issue when it came to answering certain questions--at times when dealing with such matters, it becomes complicated to give a good answer since the matter is so complex so one can only do their best.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: If you want to understand the history of Latin America through the lens of migration, take this course. The readings are engaging and interesting, ranging from historical documents and personal accounts to broader theoretical frameworks of migration. The course is a bit of a pick-your-own adventure with the essays pretty open-ended. You get out what you put in; it's possible to not be super engaged with class and do well, but you certainly gain more by reading and engaging with the concepts.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Dr. Rodriguez-Garcia is incredibly well-informed on this topic and is very enthusiastic about sharing his knowledge. The class can feel very long sometimes (a natural consequence of the 2-and-a-half-hour run time) but if you're looking to learn more about the topic, you will definitely get that here. Dr. Rodriguez-Garcia is understanding and patient and I learned a lot of things from him.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: I really enjoyed how this course found novels to highlight that were beyond the mainstream "canon". That allowed the course to really interrogate social movements in a way that others haven't, which I valued.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: The readings are a ton of pages for each class. Don't let this worry you too much. I'm not a fluent Spanish speaker and if you skim the pages and gauge a general idea for what you're reading you'll be fully equipped to participate fully in class. Come to class each time with at least 1 passage that you found interesting.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Take it! Interesting but still chill, great supportive instructor who is there to help.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Jose Maria Rodriguez-Garcia continues to be one of the best Spanish professors in the department. This was my second class with him and I look forward to taking more. Class is a lot of reading but he really boils it down to the key points and is happy to offer ideas for the 3 big essays in the course.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: It is a lot of reading but overall a manageable workload, and Profe is knowledgeable, kind, and understanding.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: take it- its really interesting and the professor is really caring and attentive, if you care you will be fine

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Be prepared to read an abundance of novels and be prepared to write insightful essays.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Definitely a rigorous course but if you are interested in Latin American literature as well as historical events of the time, this is a great class. The workload although heavy was definitely manageable and Professor Rodriguez-Garcia is very understanding and accommodating.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: I would say to definitely take the course if you are interested in reading and gaining a wider understanding of Mexican, Colombian, Venezuelan, and Cuban literature. However, keep in mind that the weekly readings are extensive, and often, there is not much clarity and structure when it comes to assignments. I enjoyed the course, but could not, unfortunately, prioritize the class as much as I wanted to due to conflicting coursework in science classes. With that being said, it is still possible to succeed in the class without doing all the readings- just make sure to show up to class, take notes, and participate.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: This is an interesting course that will immerse you in Latin American literature that you may not know as well as more canonical works. The course is lecture-heavy, relies on three long essays for your grade, and does require a large bit of reading. Keeping that in mind, I would recommend it for someone looking for an upper-level Spanish.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: analytical reading and writing, speaking/writing/reading in Spanish

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to interpret dense and complex Spanish novels, how to answer thought-provoking questions in written form, and how to research historical and political context of the novels we read.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to think critically about texts and how to research properly. I also learned how to analyze a novel in the context of history which is very important.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I improved my spanish proficiency and was able to improve my reading skills as well with all the novels we read.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Introduction to literature across Latin and Central America, deep reading and historical analysis, and analytical literary thinking.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to map literary concepts onto sociological ideas, like using the novel of Arreciefe to model the exoticization of Mexico. I also learned how to use secondary sources in order to analyze and understand the novels I am reading better, especially in the case of the novels I wrote essays on (like El Reino de Este Mundo). Finally, I also learned how to gain more confidence in using my Spanish language skills to present an argument or thesis verbally during the mini-informes.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: We learned a ton about literature and South America. We learned a lot about narco trafficking, the student protests in Mexico, and indigenous cultures.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: very in depth reading of the texts

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The laid-back and conversational nature of the class was definitely helpful as a lot of the content was quite complicated and subjective, so it was useful to be able to share different opinions and approaches.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I enjoyed that it was a small seminar class. I also enjoyed the mini-essays and the mini-informes.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The class was very laid back and conversational. It was easy to ask questions and bring up different interpretations of the books we read.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The in-class discussions were intense and insightful. The "mini informe" format was useful because it allowed me to reflect on the readings without feeling pressured to write a really polished essay or reflection. I also thought the larger essays were helpful tools to synthesize ideas that we had begun developing in class.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I liked the mini-informes (and mini-papers early on)! They are a good exercise in analyzing the books we are reading without being as overwhelming as something like a big essay. I also had a lot of fun with my own extensive informe - it was a lot of fun watching videos and looking at pictures of Venezuelan buildings.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I really liked how he assigned mini informes to all us pretty much every class that way he ensured that we were all participating. The content was very intellectually stimulating too

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: We were reading very dense latin american novels. I think the vocab and language itself in the texts we read were very high level.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The class sometimes moved too quickly through novels to be very stimulating. But the oral reports from the students were creative and helped get the other students more familiar with the themes of the novels.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: I found many of the topics we covered in the class to be quite fascinating. For instance, I remember being struck by topic such as the idea of how a leader's body and physical form is a motif in El General en su Labernito, or later the role of Mayan spirituality as a form of political resistance in Balun Canan.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The small group environment was great and being assigned to talk almost every class was very enjoyable.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned to think critically about the influence of Spain in African territories and the relationships between identity, culture, and gender.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: First, I strengthened my skill in close reading and textual analysis, learning to interpret subtle thematic layers and symbolic language beyond surface-level understanding. Second, I gained proficiency in applying interdisciplinary methods—incorporating historical research, political theory, and cultural studies—to enrich my interpretations of Spanish texts. Finally, I learned to adopt a more comparative, cross-cultural perspective when discussing identity, memory, and power structures, particularly in relation to Spain’s post-dictatorship society.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

1. reading management
2. contextualizing literature in history rather than taking it at face-value

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I really loved the novels we read and the pace at which we read them! Professor Posey is amazing and leads really thought provoking class discussions. The content of the course was super interesting as well! I also loved how we had a structure for outlines, and received feedback on our essays before our final grade. This ensured we were turning in our best work and really helped me to improve as a writer.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Alison was great at always giving us a historical background on every topic before we dived deep into it. The class was very collaborative and the readings that she gave us spanned various genres and everything was very interesting. I'd keep all of this for future years.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The readings were incredibly interesting and Dr. Posey is an amazing lecturer!

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: She created an environment that encouraged critical thinking, active engagement, and intellectual risk-taking. Her discussion-based approach, along with the structured yet flexible thematic units, allowed us to deeply explore complex ideas while connecting them across different mediums (novels, films, and essays). Weekly readings paired with analytical writing prompts helped reinforce comprehension and foster original interpretation. I would highly recommend keeping the seminar-style discussions and the balance between literary and audiovisual materials, as both were instrumental in solidifying my understanding.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

Professor Posey is super engaging and gives great individualized feedback. Great for an involved, small lecture. A short essay is due every class, which must be planned for but is manageable.
